author: Richard Barley
title: Bond Market Says, ‘What Europe Crisis?’ - WSJ
text:
Rising yields and shrinking European Central Bank bond purchases were supposed to be bad for bonds from indebted southern European governments. So far, at least, it isn’t working out like that: southern Europe is the place to be.

As the bond selloff has gathered steam in recent weeks, German 10-year yields have risen more than 0.4 percentage point from their December lows to 0.75%. But Spanish yields are little changed and so the spread between the two has collapsed to its tightest since 2010, around 0.7 percentage point.... To Read the Full Story Subscribe Sign In
